parent.style: anxious first-time mom, asks many questions

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hi there! I'm Dr. Martinez. I see we're here for little Livvy today. What's been going on?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Hi, yes. She's had this cough and congestion for about three days now. I'm really worried - she's never been sick before.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I understand this can be scary with your first baby. Tell me more about the cough - is it worse at any particular time?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: It seems worse at night and when she's lying down. And she had a reaction to amoxicillin when she had that ear infection at 4 months - got a rash all over her body.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay, noted about the nighttime symptoms. Any fever? How's her eating and sleeping?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: No fever that I can tell. She's been nursing okay but seems more fussy than usual. [baby fussing] See? She's been like this a lot.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Let me take a look at her. [examining] Her breathing sounds a bit congested but not labored. Let me listen to her chest.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Is that normal? The congestion sounds so loud to me. Should I be using a humidifier?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: [examining] Her lungs sound clear, which is good news. This looks like a typical upper respiratory infection - very common in babies.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: So it's just a cold? When will it get better? Do we need antibiotics?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Most of these viral infections resolve on their own in 7-10 days. But given her congestion, I'd like to prescribe Augmentin to prevent any secondary bacterial infection.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Wait, isn't that similar to amoxicillin? I mentioned she had that allergic reaction before...

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Oh right, let me prescribe azithromycin instead. That's in a different class and will be safer for her.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Okay, thank you. What else can I do to help her feel better? She seems so miserable.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Saline drops in her nose and a cool mist humidifier will help. Keep nursing frequently for hydration. Come back if she develops fever or trouble breathing.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Should I be worried about it getting worse? When exactly should I bring her back?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: If she has trouble feeding, seems unusually lethargic, or develops a fever over 100.4, call us right away. Otherwise, this should improve gradually over the next week.
